Title: The Swiss agri-environment scheme enhances pollinator diversity and plant reproductive success in nearby intensively managed farmland
Q6_Methods: Experimental; Observational (Includes data observed in situ OR via remote sensing if used directly)
Q18_SurveyNotes: Response vars for plant reproductive success are seed set per plant, fruit set per plant, and seed mass (only 2 slots available for responses). Choose food/fuel as relevant ES in Q12 because looking at plant repo success with respect to ag and conservation benefits. Overall study looks at mgmt type relationship with pollinator richness and diversity (broken down into pollinator guilds), mgmt type relationship with plant reproductive success, and correlation between plant reproduction and pollinator diversity; also looks at influence of distance from improved mgmt type on all of the response variables.

Title: Urban biodiversity and social inequalities in built-up cities: New evidences, next questions. The example of Paris, France
Q6_Methods: Observational (Includes data observed in situ OR via remote sensing if used directly); Social survey/Interview
Q18_SurveyNotes: Study is on the spatial pattern and clustering of socioeconomic factors and semi-natural spaces. Paper mentions three types of ecosystem functions measured as proxies for ESs (biological traits for ecosystem maintenance -- "traits" ends up being richness and diversity; presence of ecosystem engineers and sealing soil for hydro-climate regulation; and use and perception of seminary's-natural public spaces by city dwellers for cultural function). Makes composite ES index ordinal gradient of low to excellent from these three and maps that onto CBG units across Paris. Little numeric quantification of anything, other that vegetation type richness and diversity relationship to household income, which is nonlinear.
Round1_Comments: service provision by urban greenspace, distribution and variation in space

Title: Recovery Debts Can Be Revealed by Ecosystem Network-Based Approaches
Q6_Methods: Model/Data Simulation; Observational (Includes data observed in situ OR via remote sensing if used directly)
Q18_SurveyNotes: This is a cool paper, very relevant to the Kremen framework (and they didn't cite Kremen!). Study revolves around network analysis so don't quantify effect sizes of much (what Q12 gets at)... this may be a limitation of our survey instrument (i.e. this survey form) for scoring papers like these (that do model complexity, whole ecosystem networks). Authors didn't state which ecosystem service they were modeling (as reflected in Q12), but I think this could apply to either energy or maintenance of options. Indicator values and biomass modeled by site (fore reef or lagoon) and by species, functional or trophic group, recovery debt estimated for entire ecosystem based on difference indicator metrics.
Round1_Comments: uses ecosystem network approach to asses recovery in coral reef ecosystem - includes % loss in cycling efficiency and transfer efficiency
qa_note: Experiment, observation, and/or modeling methods confirmed by ND+AK review

Title: Organic farming promotes biotic resistance to foodborne human pathogens
Q6_Methods: Experimental; Observational (Includes data observed in situ OR via remote sensing if used directly)
Q18_SurveyNotes: Everything measured in this study, even soil community biodiversity, is in relation to potential to mitigate pathogen spread to food through feces in crop fields (i.e. it's all about food safety risk). So only counting y-vars towards soil protection ES (e.g. not counting diversity response towards maintenance of options ES). The general result is organic farming improves below ground beetle diversity, greater beetle diversity associated with more feces removal, reduced E. coli levels. Farm management levels are conventional, organic, and integrated. They have an SEM for above and below ground farm mgmt-beetle-soil content-feces relationships.

Title: Using citizen scientists to measure an ecosystem service nationwide
Q6_Methods: Experimental; Observational (Includes data observed in situ OR via remote sensing if used directly)
Q18_SurveyNotes: LD: For the time question, they sampled multiple points (days) over the course of the experiment - 6 sample points in 60 days. They were trying to tease apart taxon-specific effects. Interesting: The current observations of the impact of dor beetles offer large-scale proof for previous findings obtained at smaller spatial scales: that dung beetle species of high body mass may be disproportionately important for sustaining an overall ecosystem service in both temper- ate (Rosenlew and Roslin 2008) and tropical regions (Larsen et al. 2005, Slade et al. 2007, 2011). The fate of a major ecosystem service may then hinge disproportion- ately on the fate of individual, large-sized species—a finding with profound consequences for conservation priorities. Overall, we note that our general approach of estimating functional contributions of decomposer taxa as differences in mass among dung pats to which they had vs. lacked access relies on the explicit assumption that relevant taxa were present across sites. For pat- dwelling dung beetles in the genus Aphodius, this assumption was verified through direct sampling of five bait pats (see above and Appendix B). For earthworms and dor beetles, the sampling techniques employed will suffice to establish neither their presence nor their abundance. ****FLAG AS AN INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO SCALE UP ES RESEARCH - citizen science experiments *****
qa_note: For LD review only: Reclass 'other' method; For TK review only: Dissolved TK clean answer into LD clean answer

Title: Mapping social-ecological vulnerability to inform local decision making
Q6_Methods: Model/Data Simulation; Observational (Includes data observed in situ OR via remote sensing if used directly)
Q18_SurveyNotes: Paper talks about feedbacks but doesn't measure them directly. The way Q12 is structured doesn't seem well suited to capture studies like this one that provide wall-to-wall maps of ES's/resilience/vulnerability. Because it's a spatial study, it inherently addresses scale, but it's also tricky to answer Q9 for this (e.g. there are no "plots"). Ecological vulnerability and social vulnerability are not correlated in the same way consistently across space. The authors use indices for all three response variables of interest (socio-ecological vulnerability, ecol. vulnerability, and social vulnerability) with multiple factors underlying those indices. Ecological resilience index is based on a normalized "intrinsic vulnerability to fishing index" [from another model] and fish assemblage data; socio indices based on 11 indicator that they lumped into 5 components (spatial mobility, materials assets, occupational mobility, attachment, and education). All response indices are on a 0 to 1 (low to high) scale. A reader would have to dig into the supplemental material and references to fully understand how and which data are used, how models work, etc.
qa_note: Experiment, observation, and/or modeling methods confirmed by ND+AK review

Title: Partitioning spatial, environmental, and community drivers of ecosystem functioning
Q6_Methods: Model/Data Simulation; Observational (Includes data observed in situ OR via remote sensing if used directly)
Q18_SurveyNotes: Variance partitioning paper.. hard to map that on to Q12. There was no direction of effects. Paper reported how much variability each explanatory component accounted for in the data, both within region, and jointly across regions. Notes on physio-chemical environmental variables used (copied verbatim from Appendix 1 in the supplement): Physical (including slope, water depth, stream width, temperature and flow) and chemical (alkalinity, pH, conductivity, TOC, turbidity, nutrients and oxygen saturation, among others) characteristics, measured at the sampling location (local scale; in blue) or at the catchment scales (regional scale; in black) are reported1. The Dundee Hydrological Regime Assessment Method (DHRAM, (Black et al. 2005)) generated 19 parameters characterising the extent of alterations to the hydrological regimes
